comments.commentBody:
I've been thinking about this. Responsible people who care about our country MUST find out what's going on forthwith, and take steps to remedy it, immediately. If agents are actively working to criminalize a presidential candidate, especially one who's been a distinguished public servant for many years, then their heads should roll.

I'd extend that honor to their leader as well, because he obviously has tried to damage OUR election.

I am so angry about this. Who died and put a right wing faction within the FBI in control of the United States?

Mary,

Never overlook the possibility that your choice for President is in fact guilty of a number of crimes!

The DOJ and FBI were deeply involved in criminal behavior before the Watergate burglary. Look at the guilty pleas from Mitchell on down.

Don't expect anything upstanding from there. Look at Comey's actions recently.

We had all better pray that we also rescue OUR Senate and at the very  least a larger majority in the U.S. House from these fools.  These threats are not acceptable and we must be prepared to storm Congress in droves to show our displeasure if the BIG democracy-destroying money masters' obstructionists pull something like this.  No civil war in America.  We'll just make sure the obstructionists suffer from personal class action civil suits, and Justice Department action against their treasonous behavior.  The majority of us do not agree with their tactics.

I sped through this puzzle for some reason. I must have been on David's wavelength tonight.

Fun, fresh entries. I enjoyed this one. And yes, Deb, I got TOGAS right away. In fact my first pass filled in about half of the squares.

Trump has a case of rape, a case of fraud and several other law suits pending. Comey has already said that no reasonable prosecutor would bring changes against Clinton. So, what's the crime? Using the wrong server is NOT a crime.The Clinton Foundation is a highly rated charity which it seems has operated within the law. I don't agree that she is close to being in a position to be impeached under any fair judgement but she might be at the hands of vindictive politicians who care nothing for our country. You sound intelligent, Nick, but you have bought the propaganda of the Big Lie.

I recall that Ford was not re-elected because he pardoned Nixon but this is seen, now, as having been for the good of the country. We could use more men like Ford today.

I wanted roach instead of SHARD, too. (to be blunt)

I actually used STROP in a Facebook comment recently.

I confidently put in 'ROACH' right off the bat and didn't give it up until my post-walk return to the puzzle.  Then I realized that a 'ROACH' is a joint remnant, not really a pot remnant.  It was fun while it lasted, though!
My first fill there was RESIN...

Sooo disappointed that "Pot Remnant" was not "ROACH. Fit so nicely with ABOVE WATER and HOT ROASTED. I really thought I had finally gotten some benefit from my college years. Oh well...

Had to exchange my BLOODY MARY for the trendier BLACK WIDOW.
Randy Newman had a song about Short People. Pretty funny but probably will disqualify him from ever receiving the Nobel.

You can't take a step stool to the grocery store.

And now that I am old and decrepit and don't bend well, I need a reacher/grabber not only for the top shelves but for the bottom ones as well.

and Elke
Cannot resist a David S. puzzle. Tough start : had only UMA and MCCAIN. Then MARIJUANA, which is sold here legally in licensed shops, helped give me EILAT (instead of Haifa) . EILAT used to be a favourite tourist destination for sun-starved Northern Europeans in the winter.
Thought that short people (ahem) have step stools , but DEBTS fit better.
While I looked in vain for a "bra", I found enough evidence for David's continuing search : ASK ANYONE : SLOW DANCE, OO LALA, BAWDY, JONES (new word for me), CHEAP DATE all hint at a continuing search....
Did have Bloody Mary before BLACK WIDOW (know nothing of cocktails); do know of STOUT ales, though.
Some MOVERs we have used expressed their IRONY by labeling boxes containing heavy textbooks as "pillows/feathers", and vice versa.
Prefer my ahi as sushi , rather than risking overcooking it as TUNA STEAK . And I'll let the SNOW CRAB continue to SWIM under WATER.
David S. -nice puzzle ; how's school going?

I am not a baseball fan but what a World Series this was!  To go to an extra inning in the last game and win by one point?  What a game of matched skill.  Congratulations to all Cub players and fans and to The Cleveland team for some of the best baseball ever.

I only want people to be nice and willing to help me, if I need it.

What I do hate it's these stores where they have the person bagging the items and then pushing the shopping cart for the customer to their cars, without receiving any compensation for it, claiming that it's part of their service.
It really irritates me to see healthy women with their healthy kids or teenagers using their service like if they were handicapped.
I have no objection that this service should be for seniors and handicapped, but for normal, healthy lazy people... C'mon!

There is very little to smile about in the TJ's on the Upper West Side. We are regular shoppers of the Trader Joe's in the suburbs of Boston, where the mood is relaxed, service is with a smile, and shopping is easy. We tried to pick up a few things one afternoon in New York City on a weekend and to check out the Upper West side's store. The scene was like nothing we had experienced at any other TJs. So I think you're analysis is correct. And in terms of mood,despite the fact that there is a bank of check-out agents, the line to check out snaked around the store. Estimated check out wait time exceed 30 minutes. We got out as fast as we could. Happy that we weren't dependent on this particular branch. But I have to say there was nothing to smile about there. And that is a management problem.

I've been a long time TJ's  shopper on the East Coast, before they were in NYC. The small stores that sprouted up in NJ and on Long Island were considered by many as inexpensive gourmet stores offering many high quality products. When they came into the NYC market people shopping it made it there go to store for their everyday groceries needs, this is not what TJ's was about. Now that their a major grocery chain, they're dealing with a different consumer, who can't always get what they want, so I can see that at times one cannot always walk around with a smile on their face. It worked well in CA, but NY is a different beast.

I think you are putting too much into one employee. I've also shopped in TJ,in PA, having a daughter there. I found the employees very friendly. I asked them if they like working at TJ and was told by more than one, it is one of the best companies around. Some had worked at Walmart, a store who tells their employees to apply for medicaid, deliberately keeping their wages low.

In a lifetime of shopping at nearly 10 different Trader Joe's in Los Angeles and several in the Northwest, I have never once heard a manager shame an employee over the intercom system. The  behavior in the article applies only to this one very bad manager. You can visit your Pennsylvania store with a good conscience.  I have a large number of friends who've worked at Trader Joe's and they only have the best memories of working there.

"Oppressive operation?" "company policy is to engineer a hostile work environment?"

When we struck and formed a union local in the '70s, these phrases truly described life behind the wheel (and especially in the office), day in and day out.

Your flaccid generalizations are not supported by this little Times hit piece, which has selectively or negligently mined the terrain for comments from malcontents (or, as alleged above, union organizers) and stories of the odd bad employee experience, with no background or analysis.

And to those who object to occasional instances of possibly-less-than-deeply-heartfelt cheery helpfulness, I hope you don't see them as the main problems in your life, or even in your day.

Thank you very much, New York Times! I've never darkened their doors, but I'd been meaning to get to State College to visit the Trader Joe's there, if only to get their stuffed grapevine leaves, which are excellent. But to support this kind of oppressive operation? Nothing doing. Why aren't customers offended and angered, hearing the managers shame their own employees via the PA system? It's as if company policy is to engineer a hostile work environment. This reminds me simultaneously off "Office Space," "The Wall," and some dystopian novel whose title I can't remember.  I certainly hope they get that union off the ground. They need it.
It's a wonderful day when I get the connection.  Mr. Potter fits right into the mini-theme.
Martin, did the puzzle while watching the game. Same result. Didn't realize this was a DS puzzle until afterward, Sounds like the kid has gone to pot.
Similar experiences in Madison, WI, and Phoenix, AZ, Charles.

Except for the fact that the sodium content in their soups is way, way too high, the TJ's I go to somewhere between sourpuss NYC and smiley-face California is wonderful. Big enough to feel like a supermarket; small enough to feel like mom-and-pop grocery store; superb quality at remarkably affordable prices, and nary a fake smile by the cash registers, as far as I can tell. And I'm not and never have been a Trader Joe's employee. I swear.

Full timer I talked to surprised me. No 21 or 22 an hour for him! after five years. And strict rules. And major repercussions for hourly ever working over forty. Sinner! Unclean! Management very unhappy. Not the Costco living wage experience for him.

What do I care? I just shop there.

I've been shopping at Trader Joe's in South Pasadena and Los Angeles since the 1970's and I love it. It has gourmet products that you can't find elsewhere and at very low prices; they have new, seasonal products all the time; and I have always found the employees to be very helpful and friendly. Maybe the Southern California/Hawaiian atmosphere doesn't work as well in NYC, but the stores have a huge, loyal following out here.
If the bottle cost $13 would you have had the same reaction?
You must be left alone quite often.
oh c'mon Nick, now we all want to know what you did with cheap wine on a Tuesday afternoon.

I stopped shopping at Trader Joe's after an employee ringing me up asked if I had "big plans" for this $3 bottle of wine I was purchasing on a Tuesday afternoon.

Just leave me alone.

He has the right to file a lawsuit especially if they retaliated against him when he tried to unionize -some employees are not people friendly it does not mean they are not hard workers and good employees.

I live a mile from the original Trader Joe's. I have shopped there since 1979. I have met Joe Coulombe on many occasions since he sold the stores. Over the last 20 years, I have shopped there thousands of times and returned items whenever they did not meet my expectations. I have shopped at Trader Joe's on the East and West Coasts. In my opinion, the soul of the stores is the best its ever been, better than Whole Foods for example (a block away from Trader Joe's in Pasadena). If there's an issue, and there will always be issues in a large and growing organization, bring it to their attention. In my experience, they are still focused on giving the customer the best experience possible.
It's possible to hire someone genuinely cheerful and competent. Trust me.

Wrong store !
My experience everywhere else in California
is uniformly positive. But I get the sense
there could be wide geographical variation.
There's a happy medium between being miserable and having to display forced, phony cheeriness.

Do you expect your employees (and in a perfect world yourself) to smile all the time. No other expression allowed, no matter why. Just walk around staring at the air smiling.
See a customer coming in, catch his eye, smile. That's proper smile usage. Smile at an empty wall cause you are going by it. Not proper.
Walk to to a customer to help. Catch their eye, so they know you are coming to them, smile. If they are speaking of serious things put a 'listening' or serious look on your face. Smile and you are looked on as a fool. Even if it is an order.

Twenty-three years and counting, in retail, a garden center, most of it as management. Here's what I know.
If I am happy to see customers, customers are happy.
If I am happy to work with employees, employees are happy.
If I am happy, I am happy.
Who wants to be miserable 8 hours a day, five days a week? Heck, who wants to be miserable for fifteen minutes?
Retail is not for everyone and is harder than most people think. Far more people wash out than succeed and very few people are good at it.
Mr. Nagle needs to figure all this out and move on.
Come visit my state. It's very beautiful and we have a philosophy of live and let live.

I couldn't agree more.  The clearly forced positivity and false intimacy I experience at Trader Joe's is not just annoying, it's almost creepy.  I don't want  to invariably be confronted with shiny happy people: I want people who are being real, who are free to be whoever and however they are in that moment, and as a customer, I claim my right to the same.

Not mentioned in the NYT article is how are the managers managed and evaluated.
Does the practice vary from East Coast to West Coast?

It's also because it's tougher to live in the Northeast.  It's very densely populated, colder and more homogeneously expensive to live there. The workers and the customers are less happy campers before they even enter the store.

It sounds like this could be more of a local problem on the East Coast. The genuinely friendly customer service has always stood out for me in every store in every states in Pacific and Mountain time zones that I've visited. I've always believed that it must be because the employees are treated well, paid fairly and there is a spirit of camaraderie. I often see employees teamed up in pairs to stock shelves, chatting away happily while working, and neither customers nor managers seem to have a problem with it.

It sounds like some of the East Coast managers need some retraining, or that they need to be replaced with genuinely friendly and motivating people. I've never thought that the employees at my local TJ's were trained to be genuinely friendly. I've always assumed that the management hired them because they were already that way.

"I do not like clerks who try to make me happy. "

Sad.

Trader Joe's, along with other many other retailers in 2013, also cut full-time employees' hours so that they wouldn't have to offer them health insurance.
They also stopped offering health insurance to part-time workers.

Unfortunately, this campaign of forced smiles and sincerity is not limited to retailing.
During the last decade, hospitals have instituted these inauthentic "customer service" programs that are very insulting to the healthcare professionals who were already genuinely committed to helping people. For the right reasons. Not because it was "mandatory".
How about, "realistic".

Trader Joes' workers and customers in California are constantly moving. It is a place that is never at rest. I respect all of the clerks. I talk to them and give them sympathy. I compliment their T-Shirts. I am put off by Vogueing - the peculiar acting of grocery store clerks and their customers conduct while working with or buying groceries and waiting in line. I do not like clerks who try to make me happy.

In Campbell, a TJ clerk with a rough face was falsely accused by a nutty customer that he harassed her. He has rough skin. He was reprimanded and threatened with being fired, and it may have happened. He was extremely upset and I informed him that he was a great clerk who I enjoyed seeing. Though I enjoy seeing so many fresh faces at TJs, I prefer to see people earning a living wage.

TJs does not hire its workers to work full time schedules, shakes up their schedules weekly, and prohibits petitioning at in the lawful apron area of the stores. In other words, TJs attacks the constitutional and case law protected legal rights of political canvassers to collect signatures in public zones see Pruneyard case (where Campbell, Ca TJs operates). TJs has competition.
Since there is no Trader Joe's stores in Canada you must be commenting with limited experience or hearsay.   Or maybe envy disguised as sour grapes?

Draconian expectations of retail workers should be challenged not silenced. Good luck Trader Joe's with silencing Retail Wholesale's insistence on fair and humane treatment of your employees. As the complaints continue to pile up, Trader Joe's  might make the 2016 list of Worst US Retail Companies to Work For.
If it helps, most of us read the comments as essential to the story.

Wonder, you missed this year's new NYT directive, it is okay for their reporters to 100% put their bias in articles concerning the election.  It will filter down to all their other stories.  While I understand newspapers will always have a left or right slant, I still hope for some objectivity away from the editorial page.  From there we can formula our own opinion, conservative, liberal or even today's rare breed, the center where both sides can meet and compromise.
Public shaming, reprimands for conversing with fellow employees, and being forced to smile genuinely while being abused are not trivial issues.

I work at this store and have been with the company for many years. I've worked at multiple stores in different states and the people this article is talking about are just taking out personal issues with Trader Joe's.  This is a great company. I've worked at other retail stores with legitamite issues and these "issues" are  just employees knitpicking to get what they want.  I'm surprised at the New York Times for publishing this story without getting any other perspective.
